results.title: [Brent Seymour]
results.brief_description:
The Murray River Queen gets into deep and treacherous waters. People try and save it with chopsticks but alas it eventually sinks. End caption: “they’s why the Poseidon uses a fork”.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

group.title: Stamps coming to life: Anderson Creek Primary School

results.title: [Bendigo Film Library with Tricia Nankervis and Ken McLoughlin]
results.brief_description: Outlines the services that are available at the Film Lending Library in Bendigo. Discusses topics of films available and how to obtain membership and also talks about libraries in Gippsland. Mention is made of “20,000 films down in Melbourne” (State Film Centre) and “can draw on the library in Canberra”. Interviews are conducted with Tricia Nankervis and Ken McLoughlin. Of historical value.

results.title: [Behind the screen]
results.brief_description: Set in a film studio, this slapstick comedy features Charles Chaplin as David, a stage hand, in constant trouble with Goliath, played by Eric Campbell, his boss. The film ends with a pie-slinging contest in which Chaplin never gets hit. Also features Edna Purviance, Albert Austin, Lloyd Bacon and Harry Bergman. Silent film.

results.title: [B-29: frozen in time]
results.brief_description: In February 1947, a B-29 bomber nicknamed Kee Bird, became lost above the Arctic Circle while on a secret Cold War reconnaissance mission. After crash landing in northern Greenland, the crew was rescued, but the Kee Bird was left behind. Although nearly 4,000 B-29’s were built in the 1940’s, the Kee Bird was one of only a few such planes left in the world. Its historical significance and well-preserved condition attracted the attention of Darryl Greenamyer, an experienced salvage pilot. After surveying the plane and its location, Greenamyer decided to repair the Kee Bird and fly it back to the United States. This video details the harsh conditions, hard work and engineering expertise needed to repair and rescue the plane and was filmed over two summer expeditions capturing the joy and the heartache of a dedicated and determined team of men prepared to give their all to achieve Darryl Greenamyer’s dream of resurrecting the B-29. NB: No title or credits provided.

results.title: [Avalanche]
results.creator_credit: John Danischewsky, Monja Danischewsky and Children's Film Foundation
results.brief_description: Children’s adventure film set in the Tyrolean Alps. A group of young English children on a skiing holiday in the Alps find themselves in difficulty when one of them has a skiing accident and breaks his leg. Cast includes Howard Marion-Crawford, Moustache, Tarek Sharif and Totti Truman Taylor.

results.title: [Automatic profiling machine]
results.brief_description: A documentary on the Profiling Machine, including all technical aspects as well as how the machine works with different tools. (Basically the machine is used for cutting down wood to different sizes.)

results.title: [Australian olympic team visits Bayer works at Leverkusen on June 22nd 1936]
results.brief_description: Documentary from 1936 about the visit of the Australian Olympic team to the Bayer Works, manufacturers of Bayer Aspirins and APC powders, at Leverkusen, near Cologne, Germany before travelling to Berlin for the Olympic Games. The Australian Olympic team are shown arriving in Cologne, Germany, and being met by representatives of the Bayer works. They move on to a casino where they have breakfast. The team’s chaperone, Mrs. Ferguson talks to long distance runner, Daryl Backhouse. At the Bayer Works factory team members Alf Watson and Pat Norton look at a machine which fills and caps vials. The team moves on and looks at a machine which makes Bayer aspirins. At a dock on the Rhine river, where raw materials for the factory are unloaded, team members L. Cook, Duncan Gray and Bill Dixson are shown standing around and chatting. After a visit to the factory the team are shown sight seeing around Cologne. Shots of a booklet signing are followed by shots of Berlin. As the Australian team disembark from their train on their arrival at a railway station in Berlin, the German Navy are shown playing ‘God save the King’ on the station’s platform. Words of the sound film are spoken by Mr. Alderson, manager of the Australian Olympic team.

results.title: [Arthur Rubinstein]
results.brief_description: Biographical documentary about world-renowned classical pianist, Arthur Rubinstein. Born in Poland in 1887, Rubinstein first visited America in 1906, playing in Philadelphia and New York. However he finally settled in Paris until 1914 when he offered his services to the British authorities as an interpreter during the period of the war. At the end of the war he returned to America performing at numerous concerts between 1919 and 1927, but it would take until 1937 before Rubinstein finally gained full recognition. Eventually settling in Hollywood he became one of the most prolific recording and concert artists, collaborating frequently with Jascha Heifetz and Gregor Piatigorsky as part of the “Million Dollar Trio”. He died in Geneva in 1982 leaving a legacy of a multitude of television and motion picture musical scores composed over a thirty-year period. This film features interviews and performances by Rubinstein, David Oistrakj, and the Million Dollar Trio. NB: Quality of picture and sound is inconsistent.
